name: Landing Page Layout (Marketing)
description: A conversion-optimized marketing landing page layout with hero section, feature highlights, social proof, and multiple CTAs. Perfect for product launches, SaaS marketing, and lead generation campaigns.

invariants: Sections stack vertically in source order
Entire page scrolls (no nested scroll containers)
Navbar remains fixed and may transition on scroll (transparent to solid)
No horizontal page scroll is introduced
First section (hero) should be above the fold

aiAgentInstructions.summary: Implement a conversion-optimized marketing landing page layout with hero section, feature highlights, social proof/testimonials, and strategic CTAs. The layout is framework-agnostic and should adapt to the user's chosen stack (React, Vue, Angular, Svelte, etc.) and styling approach (Tailwind, CSS Modules, Chakra UI, etc.).
keyFeatures: Above-the-fold hero section with headline, subheadline, primary CTA, and hero image/video
Feature highlights section with 3-4 responsive grid cards
Social proof section with testimonials or client logos
Fixed navbar with optional scroll transition (transparent to solid)
High accessibility with semantic HTML and ARIA labels
CRITICAL: Styling MUST match the project's existing conventions. Detect framework and styling system first, then use ONLY that system. Do NOT introduce new styling systems.
CRITICAL: When detecting vanilla CSS, ALWAYS create CSS classes in a stylesheet. NEVER use inline style attributes on HTML elements.
CRITICAL: When detecting React, extract logic into separate custom hooks that do ONE thing each.
implementationSteps: 0. CRITICAL: Detect the project's framework and styling system BEFORE writing any code. Examine: (a) package.json for framework and styling dependencies, (b) existing component files to see styling patterns, (c) config files, (d) existing style files and their structure. Use ONLY the detected system.
0a. Detect framework patterns: Check how existing components are structured, how state is managed, and what patterns are used.
0b. Detect styling conventions: Identify class naming, how styles are imported, whether there's a design system or token system.
0c. If detection is uncertain, ask the user about their styling approach and framework before proceeding.
1. Create main layout component structure with sequential sections
2. Implement navbar component (fixed position, optional scroll transition)
3. Build hero section with headline, subheadline, CTA buttons, and hero media
4. Create features grid section with responsive cards (3-4 columns desktop, 2 tablet, 1 mobile)
6. Implement final CTA section before footer
7. Add footer with links and copyright
8. Implement responsive breakpoints and mobile-first styles
9. Add scroll-triggered animations for section entrance (optional, respect prefers-reduced-motion)
10. Ensure all CTAs are keyboard accessible with proper focus indicators
11. Add semantic HTML5 elements and ARIA labels for accessibility
12. Use ONLY the detected styling system. Do NOT add <style> blocks, inline styles, or new CSS files unless that's the project's convention.

react.stateManagement: useState for component state, useEffect for scroll listener, custom hooks for reusable logic
react.example: const [scrolled, setScrolled] = useState(false); useEffect(() => { const handleScroll = () => setScrolled(window.scrollY > 50); window.addEventListener('scroll', handleScroll); return () => window.removeEventListener('scroll', handleScroll); }, []);
react.customHooks: Extract scroll detection into useScrollPosition() hook. Extract intersection observer for animations into useInView() hook.

vue.stateManagement: ref() for state, onMounted() for scroll listener, provide/inject for sharing
vue.example: const scrolled = ref(false); onMounted(() => { window.addEventListener('scroll', () => { scrolled.value = window.scrollY > 50; }); });

angular.stateManagement: Component properties, RxJS for scroll events, @HostListener for scroll

svelte.stateManagement: writable stores for state, onMount for scroll listener
svelte.example: let scrolled = false; onMount(() => { window.addEventListener('scroll', () => { scrolled = window.scrollY > 50; }); });

mobileMenuReliability.when: Mobile hamburger menu must work consistently
criticalRequirements: 1. DOM Ready: Attach event listeners only after DOM is fully loaded (use DOMContentLoaded or defer/type=module script)
2. Z-Index: Hamburger button z-index must be > navbar (e.g., button: 60, navbar: 50, menu: 100)
3. Touch Targets: Button must be at least 44x44px (better: 48x48px) for reliable touch interaction
4. Pointer Events: Button must have pointer-events: auto and cursor: pointer
5. Event Propagation: Use event.stopPropagation() on button click to prevent conflicts with document-level handlers
6. Click vs Touch: Listen for both 'click' event (works for touch and mouse) rather than separate touch handlers
7. State Management: Track menu state (open/closed) to prevent race conditions
8. CSS Display: Ensure button is visible on mobile (display: flex) and hidden on desktop (display: none at ≥768px)

commonIssues.buttonNotClickable: Check z-index, pointer-events, and ensure no transparent overlays covering button
commonIssues.intermittentFailure: Event listener may be attaching before DOM ready, or being removed accidentally
commonIssues.worksInDevToolsNotOnDevice: Touch target too small, or click event not being captured properly
commonIssues.menuClosesImmediately: Document click handler is firing immediately, use stopPropagation on button click
commonIssues.buttonDisappearsOnScroll: Check if navbar transition is affecting button visibility or z-index

robustImplementation.initialization: Use 'DOMContentLoaded' event or module script with defer, check if element exists before adding listener
robustImplementation.stateTracking: Use boolean flag or class toggle to track open/closed state
robustImplementation.cleanup: For SPAs, remove event listeners on component unmount to prevent memory leaks
